review.title: Temporal Action-Graph Games: A New Representation for Dynamic Games
review.abstract: In this paper we introduce temporal action graph games (TAGGs), a novel graphical representation of imperfect-information extensive form games. We show that when a game involves anonymity or context-specific utility independencies, its encoding as a TAGG can be much more compact than its direct encoding as a multiagent influence diagram (MAID).We also show that TAGGs can be understood as indirect MAID encodings in which many deterministic chance nodes are introduced. We provide an algorithm for computing with TAGGs, and show both theoretically and empirically that our approach improves significantly on the previous state of the art.

metadata.title: Temporal Action-Graph Games: A New Representation for Dynamic Games

sections.text: In this paper, we present Temporal Action Graph Games (TAGGs), a novel graphical representation of games with imperfect information in a comprehensive form. We show that when a game includes anonymity or context-specific utility independence, its encoding as a TAGG can be much more compact than its direct encoding as a multi-agent control diagram (MAID). We also show that TAGGs can be understood as indirect MAID encodings, where many deterministic random nodes are introduced. We provide an algorithm for calculating with TAGGs and demonstrate, both theoretically and empirically, that our approach is significantly better than the current state of the art.

sections.heading: 2.3 Strategies
sections.text: We start with pure strategies, where pure strategies are generally not sufficient (for example, to guarantee the existence of the balance of Nash). We often want to consider strategies where players make decisions randomly. A player's mixed strategy i is a distribution of probability over a player's pure strategy i. However, the use of mixed strategies is problematic, as decisions can be correlated in different decisions, allowing a player to link his later choices to their earlier decisions, regardless of whether he respects those earlier decisions. In other words, mixed strategies allow a player to act as if he is observing more information than is specified in the game. We therefore limit our attention to behavioural strategies where options for action are randomized in different decisions.

sections.heading: 2.5 The Induced MAID of a TAGG
sections.text: We use a similar construction to the induced Bayesian network, but with two differences. Firstly, instead of decision variables with CPDs assigned by σ, we have decision nodes in the MAID. Secondly, each decision payout variable uτD becomes a supply node for players pl (D) in the MAID. The resulting MAID describes the same game as the TAGG because it offers agents the same strategies and their expected benefits are defined by the same BN. We call this the induced MAID of the TAGG.

sections.heading: 2.6 Expressiveness
sections.text: It turns out that TAGGs are at least as meaningful as MAIDs.Lemma 14: Each MAID can be represented as a TAGG with the same spatial complexity. As a result, TAGGs can represent any form of games that can be represented as MAIDs, including all perfect recall games and the subclass of imperfect recall games in which each amount of information does not include multiple time steps. Since the induced MAID of a TAGG is equivalent to the TAGG, it follows trivially that each TAGG can be represented by a MAID. However, the induced MAID has a large scope and can therefore be exponentially larger than the TAGG. In the games of Examples 1 and 7, for example, the induced MAID games show maximum indexes that are equal to the number of decisions, implying that the size of the GAID games for the MAID decisions grows, while the number of GAID decisions is not converted to AID-1.

sections.heading: 3 Computing Expected Utility
sections.text: A compact game representation is not very useful if we cannot perform game theory calculations efficiently in terms of the size of the representation. In this section we consider the task of calculating the expected benefit EUσ [j] for a player j given a mixed strategy profile σ. EU calculation is an essential step in many game theory calculations, such as finding the best answer given the strategy profile of other players and the iterated best response algorithm, which is guaranteed to not converge but will find a Nash balance when converging. In section 4 we discuss extending our methods in this section to a partial task in the GovidanWilson algorithm for calculating Nash balances, which are guaranteed to converge. Thus, we can achieve an acceleration of all of these calculations by accelerating their bottlenecks. An advantage of the formal definition of the EU in relation to BNs is that now the problem of calculating the EU is of course presented as a Bavarian network problem by allowing us to accelerate its inferences.

sections.heading: 4 Computing Nash Equilibria
sections.text: Since the induced MAID of a TAGG is equivalent to the TAGG, algorithms for calculating the Nash balance of MAIDs [11; 15; 2] can be applied directly to an induced MAID to find the Nash balance of a TAGG. However, this approach does not exhaust all the TAGG structures. We can do better by constructing a transformed MAID, similar to the transformed BN, taking advantage of the causal independence and CSI as described in Sections 3.1 and 3.3 and exploiting the temporal structure as described in Section 3.2 when using a solution algorithm that requires the calculation of probabilities and expected benefits. sections.heading: 5 Experiments
sections.text: We implemented our algorithm for calculating the expected service life in TAGGs and conducted experiments on the efficiency and scalability of our algorithm. We compared three approaches for calculating the expected benefit in the face of a TAGGs: Approach 1 Applying the standard clique tree algorithm (as implemented by the Bayes Net Toolbox) to the induced BN; Approach 2 Applying the same clique tree algorithm to the transformed BN; Approach 3 Applying our proposed algorithm. All approaches were implemented in MATLAB. All of our experiments were performed with a computer cluster consisting of machines with dual Intel Xeon 3.2GHz CPUs.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: TAGGs are a novel graphical representation of imperfect formation games in an extensive form. They are an extension of simultaneous AGGs to the dynamic setting and can be thought of as a sequence of AGGs played over T-time steps, with the number of actions increasing over time. This process can be formally described by the induced BN. In situations with anonymity or CSI structure, the TAGG representation can be exponentially more compact than a direct MAID representation. We presented an algorithm for calculating the expected benefit for TAGGs that uses its anonymity, CSI, and time structure. We demonstrated both theoretically and empirically that our approach is significantly more efficient than the standard approach for direct MAID representation of the same game.
